resources.string: Glimmpse Lite calculates power and sample size for one-way ANOVA designs with normally distributed outcomes.The software was developed at the Colorado School of Public Health, Department of Biostatistics and Informatics at the University of Colorado Denver. \n\nFunding was procided by NIDCR 1 R01 DE020832-01A1 to the University of Florida (Keith Muller, PI; Deborah Glueck, University of Colorado site PI).
This action will clear any unsaved study design information. Continue?
There are no email clients installed.

Glimmpse Lite was developed at the University of Colorado, Denver by Uttara Sakhadeo, Dr. Aarti Munjal and Vijay Akula with support from Drs. Sarah Kreidler and Deborah Glueck 

It is a part of a large research project to provide researchers such as behavioral and social scientists with tools and education related to the following aspects of study design. 

-Calculating power and sample size for any univariate or multivariate test for the general linear multivariate model, assuming fixed predictors. 
-Producing confidence intervals on power estimates for designs with fixed predictors. 
-Producing power calculations for designs with a single Gaussian covariate. 
-Supporting designs with unequal group sizes and complicated covariance structures. 
-Creating basic power curves. 

Additional documentation, publications and related software products are available from http://samplesizeshop.com 

For questions or report a bug, please contact us.
Click on each tab to access the help page for each input.

Glimmpse Lite calculates power and sample size for ANOVA. To perform a calculation, you will need to: 


Indicate if you would like to solve for power or sample size. 

If solving for sample size, you will specify the desired power. 

Specify the Type I error rate. 

Input the total number of groups. 

If solving for power, you will specify the size of the smallest group. 

Select equal or unequal group sizes. 

Enter choices for group means and within-group variance.


After inputting the study design, click the "Calculate" button to obtain your results. 
To access the individual help page for each of these inputs, please click the link below.

To begin your calculation, you will indicate whether you would like to solve for power or total sample size. 

Power: If you have a rough idea of the number of research participants you will be able to recruite, then solving for power may be more beneficial. 

Sample Size: If you have fewer restrictions on recruitment and would like to ensure a well-powered study, then solving for sample size is likely to be more useful.

string.name: description_tutorial_alpha
string.p:
A Type I error occurs when a scientist declares a difference when none is actually present. 

The Type I error rate is the probability of a Type I error occuring and is often referred to as alpha value. Type I error rates range from 0 to 1. The most commonly used values are 0.01, 0.05 and 0.1. 

The Type I error screen allowes you to specify a single Type I error rate.

string.name: description_tutorial_groups
string.p: A one-way ANOVA design compares means amongst two or more groups. Use the seek bar to specify the number of groups in your study design. \nGlimmpse Lite currently supports designs with up to ten groups.

string.name: description_tutorial_relative_size
string.p:
Specify whether the study subgroups are of equal or unequal size. 

For equal sizes, select a "1" using the seek bar next to each study subgroup. This is the default study design. 

For unequal group sizes, you will specify the ratio of the group sizes. For example, cosider a design with an active drug group and a placebo group. If twice as many study participants receive the placebo, a value of "2" would be selected for the placebo group, and a value of "1" would be selected for the active drug group.

string.name: description_tutorial_smallest_group
string.p: If you are solving for power, you will need to specify the sample size for your study. \n\nOn the Smallest Group Size screen, you will enter the number of participants in the smallest group in the study. If your group sizes are equal, the value is the same for all groups.

string.name: description_tutorial_power
string.p:
When solving for sample size, you will need to specify the desired power for your study. 

Power values are numbers between 0 and 1. Higher values correspond to a greater likelihood of rejecting the null hypothesis. Common values are 0.8 or 0.9, although 0.9 or higher is usually preferred. 

On the Power screen, enter the desired power for your study in the textbox and click the "Add" button.

string.name: description_tutorial_mean_variance
string.p: In power analysis it is necessary to provide means and variances. The values are often obtained from published results or pilot data. Glimmpse Lite currently assumes equal variance across the groups. \n\nTo access the Means and Variance screen, you will first need to specify the number of groups. The Means and Variance screen allows the user to eneter the mean values they expect to observe for each study group. The user will also enter a single within group variance which will be shared across the groups.

resources.string:
Power results are displayed in a table with each row representing an individual power calculation. If multiple values are specified for desired power or smallest group size, then multiple rows will be displayed in the table. 
Each row shows the total sample size for the study and the associated power value. 

The user may email the results in a comma delimited format by clicking the “Email” button.
Select the number of groups in the study design.
Enter Type I Error rate for the analysis.
Specify the number of study participants in the smallest group. \n\nYou may add up to five values: power or sample size will be calculated for each value you choose.
\nTo begin your calculation, please indicate whether you would like to solve for power or total sample size.
Please fill in the details for mean and variance.
Select the relative group size for each group. For equal group sizes, select "1" for all groups.
Please update the Sample Size details.
Thank you for using the GLIMMPSE software. Your power results are attached to this email. \n\nTo learn more about power and sample size, please visit http://samplesizeshop.org.
This will lose the information. Do you want to proceed?
